user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_LoadRetval:
```c
bool UT_LoadRetval(void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize, const UT_RetvalBuf_t *Buf, UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre)
{
    switch (UT_GENRE_SIZE(ValueGenre, ValueSize))
    {
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int8)):
            *((int8 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int16)):
            *((int16 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int32)):
            *((int32 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int64)):
            *((int64 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(float)):
            *((float *)ValuePtr) = Buf->FloatingPt;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(double)):
            *((double *)ValuePtr) = Buf->FloatingPt;
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_POINTER, sizeof(void *)):
            *((void **)ValuePtr) = Buf->Ptr;
            break;

        default:
            return UtAssert_Failed("Cannot load return value - ValueSize not valid");
    }

    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UT_LoadRetval:
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(double)):
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The case label uses the macro UT_GENRE_SIZE (a compile-time computation) and the sizeof operator; there is no call to UT_LoadRetval in the fragment. The only function call in the function body is UtAssert_Failed in the default branch, which would only be a violation if that function (or UT_GENRE_SIZE) called back into UT_LoadRetval — there is no evidence of that here.
